RESUMO

A Formação Teresina, Neopermiano da Bacia do Paraná, é uma unidade
estratigráfica principalmente terrígena, com algumas ocorrências de fácies carbonáticas,

sendo depositada durante a última fase regressiva do mar epicontinental da bacia. O

ambiente deposicional da Formação Teresina, especialmente no que se refere às suas

facies carbonáticas, ainda é alvo de debate. As fácies carbonáticas da Formação
Teresina e fácies evaporíticas associadas ocorrem em toda a formação, mas são mais

freqüentes no norte do Estado do Paraná e no sul do Estado de São Paulo, na porção

superior da unidade. Esta região constitui a área de estudo desta dissertação, que visou

interpretar os processos sedimentares básicos, assim como fatores tectônicos e

climáticos que influenciaram a formação destes depósitos carbonáticos e evaporíticos.

Para isto, foram utilizadas informações de poços e realizados levantamentos detalhados

de seções colunares, com coleta de amostras para análises petrográficas por microscopia

óptica e microscopia eletrônica de varuedura (MEV). Foram identificadas e descritas

oito facies carbonáticas e/ou evaporíticas: mudstone com conchas de ostracodes,

mudstone peloidal, packstone bioclástico, waclctone bioclástico, boundstone lab:ular,

packstone-grainstone oolífico, brecha de mudstone-chert e chert enterolítico-nodular. O

sistema deposicional foi interpretado como uma rampa carbonática com zona interna

alta protegida po¡ barreiras arenosas influenciadas por ondas e correntes associadas. Nas

partes mais rasas, os períodos áridos e de intensa evaporação e baixo aporte terrígeno

provocariam aumento da salinidade e induziria a deposição das fácies evaporíticas de

cherl enterolilico-nodular e brecha de mudstone-chert. A porção intermediaria
corresponderia à zona protegida da ação das ondas, com águas rasas e baixa energia.

Isto permitiria a deposição de sedimentos hnos por decantação, que constituem as fücies

mudstone com conchas de ostracodes e wachstone bioclástico. Nesta mesma porção, as

condições geoquímicas da água teriam incentivado atividade microbiana, gerando as

fâcies mudstone peloidal e boundslone tabular. Bandas ricas em dolomita identificadas

em fácies de boundstone tabular no norte do Estado do Paraná estariam relacionadas

com precipitação mineral induzida por atividade microbiana. Filamentos e
nanoestrufuras orgânicas observadas podem coresponder a remanescentes fossilizados

de extracellular polymeric substance (EPS), usados por bactérias redutoras de sulfato

nos procesos de precipitação da dolomita-cal cita. A ação das ondas causava agitação

constante da âgua, o que originaria a sedimentação das fácies pachstone-graînstone



oolítico em baixios e das fácies heteroliticas terrígenas em zona distal entre o nível de

base das ondas de tempo bom e o nível de base das ondas de tempestade. Mapas de

isópacas e de freqüência de oconência de calcários elaborados a partir da integração dos

dados de poços e seções colunares dmonstraram aumento da concentração de calcários

no flanco noÍe do Arco de Ponta Grossa (APG). A espessura da formação aumenta em

direção ao APG. Em algumas regiões próximas ao APG, as isópacas tornam-se
paralelas ao eixo desta estrutura tectônica. Os resultados obtidos sugerem que o Arco de

Ponta Grossa atuou como barreira geográfica que restringiu a entrada de águas do

oceano vindas do sul e influenciou a deposição das fácies carbonáticas e evaporíticas. A

restrição da circulação das águas promoveu o aumento da salinidade na área
imediatamente ao norte do arco. Além disso, uma provável zona de convergência de

ventos paralela ao Arco de Ponta Grossa e situada ao sul da área de estudo teria
dificultado a entrada de massas de ar úmido provenientes do Oceano Panthalassa vindas

de sul. Isto favoreceu a instalação de condições áridas na área de estudo. O significado

tectônico e climático das fácies carbonáticas e evaporíticas da Formação Teresina
podem auxiliar as correlações entre a Bacia do Paraná e bacias na África, tais como as

bacias do Huab e Karoo, além de contribuir para reconstruções paleogeográficas do

Gondwana no final do Permiano.

ABSTRACT

The Teresina Formation, Late Permian of the Paraná Basin, is mainly composed

of tenigenous sediments, with some occuffences of carbonate and evaporite facies. It

corresponds to the upper portion of the last regressive phase of the Paraná Basin
epicontinental sea. The depositional system responsible for the carbonate and evaporite

facies of the Teresina Formation is still target of discussion. These facies occur in a

huge area of the basin, but they have a greater thickness and are more frequent in the

north ofthe Paraná State and in the southern of the São Paulo State, in the upper porlion

of the formation. This region constitutes the study area of this dissertation in order to

interpret the depositional processes as well as the tectonic and climatic factors acting

during the formation of these deposits. The study included the interpretation of data

from wells, detailed description of columnar sections, with sampling for petrographical

analysis under the optical and scanning electron microscopes (SEM). Eight carbonate

and/or evaporite facies were identified: mudstone with ostracod shells, peloidal

mudstone, bioclastic wackstone, bioclastic packestone, tabular boundstone, oolitic

packstone-grainstone, nodular and enterolithic cherl and mudstone-chert breccia. The

depositional system was interpreted as a carbonate ramp with a protected zone by

growth of oolitic sand bars and sediment transpoft dominated by wave action and

associated currents. In the inner regions, arid periods of intense evaporation and low

teruigenous input would increase the salinity, causing the deposition of enterolithic and

nodular chert and mudstone-chert breccia facies. The intermediate portion corresponds

to a lagoon with shallow and low energy waters, allowing the deposition of fine grained

sediments recorded in the mudstone with ostracod shells and bioclastic wackstone

facies. In the same portion, the hypersaline conditions of the water would have

stimulated microbial activity, promoting the deposition of peloidal mudstone and

tabular boundstone facies. Dolomite bands identified in the tabular boundstone facies in

the noÉh of the Paraná State are enriched in organic matter and they would be

associated to mineral precipitation induced by microbial activity. Organic filaments and

nanostructures may correspond to fossilized remains of extracellular polyrneric
substance (EPS), which are used by sulfate-reducing bacteria in the precipitation of

dolomite-calcite. The wave action remobilized bottom sediments, causing constant

waters agitation. This induced sedimentation of oolitic packstone-grainstone facies in

shoals and the teruigenous heterolithic facies between the fair-weather and storm wave



bases. Maps of isopachs and frequency of occurrences of limestones show concentration

of limestones in the north flank of the Ponta Grossa Arch (PGA). The thickness of the

formation increases from south to north towards the PGA. In some regions near the

PGA, isopachs are parallel to the axis of this tectonic structure. The obtained results

suggest that the Ponta Grossa Arch influenced the deposition of the carbonate and
evaporite facies of the Teresina Formation, acting as a geographical barrier that
restricted the entry of ocean waters from south. This promoted reduced terrigenous

input, low water circulation and the increase of salinity in the northern flank of the
PGA. Fufthermore, a possible winds convergence zone, parallel to the Ponta Grossa

Arch, would affected the climatic conditions in the study region during the Late
Permian. difficulting the northward migration of wet air masses coming from the
Panthalassa Ocean. This favored arid conditions in the study area. The tectonic and

climatic significance of the carbonate and evaporite facies of the Teresina Formation

have important implications for correlations between the Paraná Basin and basins from

Africa, such as the Karoo and Huab basins, as well as for paleogeographic
reconstructions of the Gondwana in the Permian.

Key-words: carbonate and evaporite facies, stromatolites, Teresina Formation, Paraná

Basin, Permian, Gondwana.



Apresentação

Esta disserlação inclui texto introdutório, que envolve os objetivos do estudo,

contexto geológico da Formação Teresina e a discussão integrada dos resultados,

acompanhada das principais conclusões. Os resultados e suas interpretações detalhadas

são apresentados na forma de dois afigos anexos. O aftigo Tectonic-climate controls

O segundo artigo intitulado Calcite-dolomite lamination and organic

1. TNTRODUÇÃO
A Bacia do Paraná é uma gigantesca bacia de tipo intracratônico, com uma área

aproximada de 1.600.000 km2, que se localiza no sul do Brasil, nos estados de Mato Grosso,

Mato Grosso do Sul, Goiás, Minas Gerais, São Paulo, Paraná, Santa Catarina e Rio Grande do

sul; no nofte e noroeste do Uruguay; e na Argentina e Paraguay (Fig. 1).

Diversos estudos já foram realizados sobre a Formação Teresina (Fanton el a1.,2006;

Neregato et a|.,2008 Rohn,2007, Milani et a1.,2007, Neves ¿/ al.,2010,Holz et a1.,2010),

mas a maior pafte destes trabalhos concentrou-se em aspectos da paleontologia e estratigrafia,

de modo que ainda há poucos estudos de detalhe sobre as suas fácies carbonáticas,

especialmente os microbialitos. Os estudos sobre as fácies evaporíticas da Formação Teresina

também são escassos. Assim, esta disseÍação trata das características petrográficas,
distribuição regional, geometria e do ambiente deposicional destas fácies. O estudo destes

temas serviria para aprofundar o conhecimento acerca dos controles sobre a gênese de fácies

carbonáticas e evaporíticas e o seu eventual uso como modelo de reservatórios carbonáticos

de petróleo e gás.

Os controles que influenciaram a sedimentação das fácies carbonáticas e evaporíticas

da Formação Teresina constituiriam informação importante para o entendimento da evolução

da paleogeograha do sul do Gondwana durante o Permiano, além de permitir correlações com

as unidades equivalentes em bacias da África.

Os objetivos principais desta dissertação são a caracterização macroscópica e
microscópica das fácies carbonáticas e evaporíticas da Formação Teresina e a descrição da

distribuição geográfica destas fácies. Os métodos utilizados nesta pesquisa foram a análise

petrográfica, a análise de fácies em afloramentos e caracterização da espessura e distribuição

espacial das facies carbonáticas por meio de dados de poços. lsto envolveu a elaboração de

colunas estratigráficas de detalhe, análise de paleocorrentes e microscopia óptica e eletrônica

de varedura (MEV). Para diferenciar minerais carbonáticos ao microscópio óptico, as seções

delgadas foram tingidas com alizarina vermelha e ferricianato de potássio diluído em HCI

2, Aspectos geológicos da área de estudo

2.1 Consideracões litoestratigráficas

O termo Estrada Nova foi utilizado pela primeira vez por White (1908), para

denominar uma seqüência formada por folhelhos cinza e variegados e arenitos, que aflora na



estrada entre as cidades de Lauro Müller e São Joaquim (SC). Moraes Rego (1930) empregou

pela primeiravez o termo Teresina, para designar os sedimentos da Fonnação Estrada Nova

encontrados na margem direita do rio Ivaí perto da Cidade de Teresa Cristina (PR).

Maack (1947) sugeriu uma possível correlação da Formação Estrada Nova com as

unidades permianas da África do Sul. Gordon Jr (1947) subdividiu a Formação Estrada Nova

nos membros Serra Alta (membro inferior) e Teresina (membro superior). O Membro Serra
Alta corresponderia aos 30 a 40 m superiores da Formação lrati de White, enquanto que o

Membro Teresina incluiria, de acordo com Gordon Jr (1947): "os .þlhelhos calcí/eros,

arenitos ./ìnos ou calcririos arenosos e calcários oolíticos parcial ou inteiramente
silicificados " .



Neste trabalho, é ttltlizada a nomenclatura estratigráfica de Schneider et al. (197 4),

que subdivide o Grupo Passa Dois nas formações: Irati, Sena Alta, Teresina e Rio do Rasto,

nas porções central e sul da Bacia do Paranâ. A nofte do lineamento do Rio Tietê, nos estados

de São Paulo, Mato Grosso e Goiás, o Grupo Passa Dois está formado pelas formações Irati e

Corumbataí.

A partir da década de 1960, foram publicados va¡ios trabalhos sobre a estratigrafia da

Bacia do Paraná, entre os quais encontra-se o estudo de Norlhfleet et al. (1969), que faz

integração de dados geológicos e apresenta características litológicas, contatos e espessuras

das unidades estratigráficas. Destaca-se também o trabalho de Daemon & Quadros (1970),
que através da análise palinológica sugerem idades para as unidades que compõem o Grupo

Passa Dois.

A Formagão Teresina faz pafie da porção superior do Grupo Passa Dois e foi definida

como uma sucessão sedimentar composta predominantemente por siltitos, com algumas

camadas de arenitos, calcários e silexitos.

O sistema deposicional responsável pela sedimentação da Formação Teresina ainda é

objeto de discussão, principalmente em relação ao ambiente deposicional, se marinho ou

lacustre, e aos processos sedimentológicos que geraram as estruturas sedimentares
(Figueiredo Filho, 1972; Lavina, 1991; Rohn, 1994; Elias el a1.,2000). Schneider e/ a/.

(197 4), Zaine (1980), Petri & Coimbra (1982) e Sousa ¿¡ al. (1991) interpretam que esta
formação se depositou em ambiente marinho raso, com planícies de maré. Holz et al. (2010)

sugerem que a Formação Teresina é produto de sistema deposicional de costa-afora a planície

costeira, influenciado por tormentas.

Segundo Runnegar & Newell (1971), a malacofauna das formações Serra Alta,
Teresina e do Membro Serrinha é endêmica. O endemismo dos bivalves e outros
invertebrados indicaria a falta de conexão direta entre a Bacia do Paraná e o Ooeano
Panthalassa (Maranhão, 1995; Simões et a1., 1998; Mello, 1999). Já na década de 1954 alguns

autores tinham identificado o isolamento da Bacia do Paraná durante a deposição da
Formagão Teresina. Beurlen (1954, 1955) sugeriu uma bacia de mar intracontinental, de baixa

salinidade, com conexão estreita e rasa com o oceano abeÍo. Rohn (2007) sugeriu um mar

epicontinental sem ligação com o Oceano Panthalassa.

No centro-sul do Estado de São Paulo, a Formação Teresina situa-se entre as

formações Serra Alta, abaixo, e Pirambóia, acima. O contato entre as formações Teresina e

Serra Alta é transicional (Rohn, 2001; Meglhioratti, 2006), caracferizado pelo aumento

ascendente de rochas heterolíticas cinza e bioturbação. Nos estados do Paraná e Santa



Catarina, o contato entre as formações Teresina e o Membro Serrinha (Formação Rio do

Rasto), de acordo com Meglhioratti (2006), é abrupto e corresponderia ao aparecimento de

grandes corpos de arenitos com grânulos e intraclastos na base. No Estado de São Paulo, o

contato entre o Grupo Passa Dois e a Formação Pirambóia é discordante para Soares (1973) e

Caetano-Chang (1993), e concordante, de acordo com Matos (1995), Giannini et al. (2004) e

Mílaú et al. (2007).

O equivalente estratigráfico das formações Serra Alta e Teresina é a Formação
Corumbataí, a qual está restringida ao norte e nordeste da Bacia do Paraná (Schneider et a/.,

1974). Porém, de acordo com Ragonha (1984), a fauna de Xenacanthus encontrada na

Formação Corumbataí se estenderia até o Triássico, idade mais jovem que a comumente

atribuída à Formação Teresina, de idade Permiana. A espessura da Formação Teresina é de

aproximadamente 280-330 metros na parte central na borda leste da Bacia do Paraná (Holz et

a|.,2010).

Milani e/ al. (1994,2007) reconheceram que a Bacia do Paraná foi influenciada por

ciclos eustáticos-tectônicos e dividiu o seu preenchimonto em seis supersequências: Rio Ivaí

(Eo-Ordoviciano * Eosiluriano), Paraná (Devoniano), Gondwana I (Eocarbonífero -
Eotriássico), Gondwana II (Triássico), Gondwana III (Neojurássico - Eocretáceo) e Bauru
(Cretáceo) (Fig. 2). O Grupo Passa Dois, que pertence à superseqüência Gondwana I, registra

tendência regressiva e o isolamento progressivo da Bacia do Pa¡aná.

Na Bacia do Para¡á foram caracterizados dois sistemas petrolíferos efetivos (Milani &

Zalan, 1999, Arlur & Soares, 2002), o sistema Ponta Grossa - I|a:ø;ré e o sistema lrati-Rio
Bonito - Pirambóia. A Formação Teresina constitui parte deste último sistema, que é
considerado atípico, pela influência de magmatismo básico cretáceo na geração e migração

dos hidrocarbon el.os (Zalan et aL, 1991, Araújo et a1.,2000).

4. Discussão

Salienta-se que a discussão detalhada dos resultados enconha-se nos artigos anexos. A

análise das fácies carbonáticas e evaporíticas da Formação Teresina foi abordada em escalas

diferentes, visa¡do a interpretagão do sistema deposicional e dos fatores tectônicos e
climáticos que afetaram a sedimentação desta unidade geológica. Na escala sub-milimétrica, a

micoscopia eletrônica de varredura (MEV) demonstrou a presença de minerais evaporíticos

nas fácies mudstone com conchas de ostracodes e brecha de mudstone-cherl, como halita e

outros mierais que poderiam indicar influência de fluidos salinos na sedimentação, tais como

bárita com estrôncio e gipsita. A análise ao MEV também evidenciou a excelente preservação

das estruturas orgânicas (biofilmes) na fácies boundstone tabular. Bandas de dolomita

enriquecidas com matéria orgânica foram identificadas por microscopia de fluorescência por

luz ultravioleta, sugerindo origem biogênica para os níveis dolomíticos da fácies boundstone

tabular.

Na área de estudo, as fácies tenígenas hete¡olíticas são resultado da alternância entre

os processos trativos e de decantação de sedimentos finos por coffentes e ondas influenciadas

por tormentas. Fácies de nódulos e níveis enterolíticos de silexito (substituição diagenética)

foram depositadas por episódios de intensa evaporação e concentração de sais em ambientes

de águas rasas com baixo aporte terrígeno. A ação das ondas geram remobilização de grandes

quantidades de sedimentos e produzem agitação constante da âgta, originando as fácies de

pacl<stone-grainstone oolíticas e pacl<stone bioclóstico, Fácies de mudstone com conchas de

ostracodes e wackslone seriam originadas por decantação de sedimentos finos em área

protegida das ondas induzidas por tormentas. Em águas rasas com periódica exposição

subaérea, foram depositadas as fácies de brechas mudstone-chert. A atividade microbiana em

ambiente protegido com alta salinidade e de águas rasas teria provocado a formação das fácies

de boundstone tabular e mudstone fenestral.

Observou-se na análise regional o incremento na freqüência de ocorrência de facies

carbonáticas no flanco nofte do Arco de Ponta Grossa , com as maiores freqüências na região

de estudo. Além disso, o mapa de isópacas gerado a parlir de informações de poços

demonstrou aumento da espessura da Formação Teresina de sul para norte em direção ao

Arco de Ponta Grossa.

A evolução sedimentar da Bacia do Paraná foi fortemente influenciada por estruturas

tectônicas, entre as quais destaca-se o Arco de Ponta Grossa. Esta estrutura teria afetado tanto

a unidades mas velhas (desde o Devoniano) como a unidades mais recentes que a Formação

Teresina. O mapa de isópacas das unidades do Carbonífero (Zalan et al.,1990) demonstra que

t3



abacia teria se dividido em duas sub-bacias, sendo o limite entre elas o Arco de Ponta Grossa.

A Formação lrati (Eopermiano ao Permiano Médio) foi resultado de sedimentação em
ambiente restrito e com condições climáticas áridas, permitindo a formação de evaporitos e

calcários (Hachiro, 1991; Hachiro, 2000; Milani et al., 2007). Yieira et al. (1991) propõem

que o Alinhamento de Guapiara (limite norte do Arco de Ponta Grossa) teria atuado como

uma barreira tectônica-ecológica-biológica, restringindo a zona d,o Stereosternum e
Brazilosaurus ao norte e a zona de Mesosaurus ao sul do alinhamento. O controle do Arco de

Ponta Grossa na sedimentação do Permo-Triássico também foi observado nas fácies eólicas e

fluviais da Formação Pirambóia. Giannini et al. (2004), por meio de análise de direções de

estratificações cruzadas, interpretaram vma zora de convergência de ventos localizada entre

os limites sul e norte do Arco de Ponta Grossa. O deslocamento desta zona para o flanco sul

do Arco de Ponta Grossa bloquearia a entrada de masas de ar úmido que vinhan do Oceano

Panthalassa em direção ao nofte da Bacia do Paraná. Esta configuração palegeográfica-

paleoclimática seria favorável ao desenvolvimento de zona árida no flanco norte do Arco de

Ponta Grossa.

Durante a sedimentação da Formacao Teresina, a falta de comunicação com o mar

aberto ao sul da Bacia teria induzido a formação de um ambiente com circulação restrita ao

norte do Arco de Ponta Grossa, promovendo a deposição das fácies evaporíticas e
carbonáticas descritas neste estudo e o endemismo dos bivalves desta unidade e das
formações Serra Alta e Corumbataí (Ghilardi & Simões, 2002).

O sul do Gondwana foi afetado por eventos tectônicos importantes, como a Orogenia

de San Rafael durante o Permo-Triássico, que produziu depressões e paleoaltos, e a formação

de um rift entre África e América do Sul (Stollhofen, 1999). O Arco de Ponta Grossa poderia

estar relacionado às grandes zonas de falhas de transferência transversais ao eixo do rift

(Stollhofen et a1.,2000), as quais gerariam vários depocentros alinhados entre si. A Formação

Teresina na ¡írea de estudo poderia ter sido resultado de sedimentação na margem de algum

desses depocentros. A Bacia do Huab na África é interpretada como um equivalente marginal

da Bacia do Paraná (Horsthemke et a|.,1990). A sedimentacão da Formação Gai-As da Bacia

do Huab, unidade conelacionável à Formação Teresina, também é interpretada como

resultado da sedimentação em ambiente fechado com circulação restrita. Esta informação

indicaria uma história deposicional semelhante entre as duas formações ao norte do Arco de

Ponta Grossa, sugerindo um provável depocentro comum.

5, Conclusões

A sedimentação da Formação Teresina apresenta uma história deposicional diferente

ao nofie e ao sul do Arco de Ponta Grossa. O isolamento geográfìco relacionado à evolução

tectônica do sul do Gondwana e uma zona de convergência de ventos provocaram a
sedimentação das fácies carbonáticas e evaporiticas da Formação Teresina. O Arco de Ponta

Grossa teria atuado como uma grande baneira geográfrca, influenciando os ventos, a

precipitação, o aporte sedimentar terrígeno, a entrada das águas oceânicas do Panthalassa

provenientes do sul e o intercâmbio biológico. Este isolamento promoveu condições
climáticas áridas e a produção de corpo d'água hipersalino. Estas condições ecológicas

estressantes, além de permitir a sedimentação das fácies carbonáticas e evaporiticas, também

proveriam um ambiente propício para a formação de níveis de estromatólitos. Estas novas

informações auxiliariam nas correlações entre as unidades permianas das bacias do Paraná e

do Huab, colaborando para a intelpretação da paleogeografia do sul do Gondwana e da

evolução tectônica da borda leste da Bacia do Paraná e sua relação com o rift permiano

africano.

ABSTRACT

The Teresina Formation, Late Permian of the Paraná Basin, is mainly composed of

terrigenous sediments, with some occurrences of carbonate and evaporite facies. It
corresponds to the upper portion of the last regressive phase of the Paraná Basin
epicontinental sea. The depositional system responsible for the carbonate and evaporite facies

ofthe'Ieresina Formation is still target of discussion. These facies occur in a huge area ofthe

basin, but they have a greater thickness and are more frequent in the north of the Paraná State

and in the southern of the São Paulo State, in the upper portion of the formation. This region

constitutes the study area of this dissertation in order to interpret the depositional processes as

well as the tectonic and climatic factors acting during the formation of these deposits. The

study included the interpretation of data from wells, detailed description of columnar sections,

with sampling for petrographical analysis under the optical and scanning electron microscopes

(SEM). Eight carbonate and/or evaporite facies were identified: mudstone with ostracod

shells, peloidal mudstone, bioclastic wackstone, bioclastic packestone, tabular boundstone,

oolitic packstone-grainstone, nodula¡ and enterolithic chert and mudstone-chert breccia. The

depositional system was interpreted as a carbonate ramp with a protected zone by growth of

oolitic sand bars and sediment transport dominated by wave action and associated currents. In

the inner regions, arid periods of intense evaporation and low terrigenous input would

increase the salinity, causing the deposition of enterolithic and nodular chert and mudstone-

chert breccia facies. The intermediate portion corresponds to a lagoon with shallow and low

energy waters, allowing the deposition of fine grained sediments recorded in the mudstone

with ostracod shells and bioclastic wackstone facies. In the same portion, the hypersaline

conditions of the water would have stimulated microbial activity, promoting the deposition of

22



peloidal mudstone and tabular boundstone facies. Dolomite bands identified in the tabular

boundstone facies in the north of the Paraná State are enriched in organic matter and they

would be associated to mineral precipitation induced by microbial activity. The wave action

remobilized bottom sediments, causing constant waters agitation. This induced sedimentation

of oolitic packstone-grainstone facies in shoals and the terrigenous heterolithic facies between

the fair-weather and storm wave bases. Maps of isopachs and frequency of occurrences of

limestones show concentration of limestones in the north flank of the Ponta Grossa Arch
(PGA). The thickness of the formation increases from south to north towards the PGA. In

some regions near the PGA, isopachs are parallel to the axis of this tectonic structure. The

obtained results suggest that the Ponta Grossa Arch influenced the deposition of the carbonate

and evaporite facies ofthe Te¡esina Formation, acting as a geographical barrier that restricted

the entry of ocean waters from south. This promoted reduced terrigenous input, low water

circulation and the increase of salinity in the northern flank of the PGA. Furlhermore, a
possible winds convergence zone, parallel to the Ponta Grossa Arch, would affected the

climatic conditions in the study region during the Late Permian, diff,rculting the northward

migration of wet air masses coming from the Panthalassa Ocean. This favored arid conditions

in the study area. The tectonic and climatic significance of the carbonate and evaporite facies

of the Teresina Formation have important implications for correlations between the Paraná

Basin and basins from Africa, such as the Karoo and Huab basins, as well as for
paleogeographic reconstructions of the Gondwana in the Permian.

Keywords: Gondwana, Paraná Basin, Ponta Grossa Arch, Teresina Formation, carbonate and

evaporite facies.

1. Introduction

In the Paraná Basin, the Teresina Formation represents the end of the Permian

epicontinental sea in the southwestern Gondwana (Milani et al., 1994; Milani e¡ al.,2007;

Rohn, 2007; Holz et a1.,20i0). This period is highlighted to record a global event of mass

extinction (Jia et al.,2012).

In the last decades, most studies about the Teresina Formation have been focused on

paleontological aspects (Fanton et aL.,2006; Neregato et a|.,2008; Rohn, 2007, Neves ¿l ø/.,

2010). Despite its formal definition in 1908, few works emphasized the sedimentological

characteristics and the controls on temporal and spatial variability ofthe sedimentary facies of

the Teresina Formation as well as their relation with its paleontological records. In this

23



context, we stand out the eastern border of the Paraná Basin in the states of São Paulo and

Paraná, where the Teresina Formation comprises siliciclastic, carbonate and evaporite facies,

representing a mixed depositional system, which is poorly reported in previous studies. It is

presented a depositional model for the carbonate and evaporite facies, based on facies and

petrographical analyses using wells and outcrops data. The carbonate and evaporite sediments

are valuable indicators of environmental conditions, such as salinity, temperature and water

depth because, contrary to siliciclastic sediments, carbonate and evaporite sediments are
formed within sedimentary basins. Tectonic and climate controls on the spatial distribution of

the Teresina Formation carbonate and evaporite facies as well as their relation with correlative

stratigraphic units in Africa are discussed in the context of the Gondwana during the Late

Permian.

The Huab Basin in Africa is interpreted as a marginal equivalent of the Paraná Basin

in the Gondwana (Horsthemke et al., 1990). Thus, the carbonate and evaporite sediments of

the Teresina Formation can give valuable information regarding the plaeoclimate and

paleorelief of the southwestern Gondwana during the Permian, allowing correlations vvith the

stratigraphical units from the Huab Basin and improving paleogeography reconstructions.

Additionally, from Late Permian to Early 'friassic, the southwestem of Gondwana was
affected by the San Rafael Orogeny Q.lewell, 1973) and Cabo-La Ventana Orogeny (Milani

and Ramos, 1998). These orogenies produced intense volcanism and confinement of

epicontinental seas that possilby influenced the sedimentation of the Paraná Basin and the

shift between the deposition of terrigenous and carbonate and evaporite facies of the Teresina

Formation.

3. Geologial background

The Teresina Formation is part of the giant cratonic Paraná Basin in central-eastern

South America. The sedimentation in this basin would be controlled by tectonic cycles, that

promoted a discontinuous depositional history (Milani, 1997; Milani et a\.,2007). According

to these authors, the stratigraphic succession of the Paraná Basin can be divided into six
supersequences: Rio Ivaí (Lower Ordovician to Lower Silurian), Paranâ (Devonian),
Gondwana I (Early Carboniferous to Early Triassic), Gondwana II (Triassic), Gondwana III
(Late Jurassic to Early Cretaceous) and Bauru (Cretaceous). The Teresina Formation belongs

to the Passa Dois Group, which conesponds to the upper part of the Gondwana I
Supersequence, recording gradual isolation and drying of the Paraná Basin epicontinental sea

(Fig.2).

The Teresina Formation outcrops in the eastern border of the Paraná Basin. This unit

consists mainly of heterolithic rocks composed of siltstones interbeded with very fine
sandstones (linsen, flaser and wavy lamination) presenting clastic dykes, with minor

4. Material and Methods

The study of the carbonate and evaporite facies ofthe Te¡esina Formation was canied

out in different scales: micrometric to millimetric (scanning electron and optical microscopy

analyses), centimetric to metric (facies analysis and stratigraphic sections in outcrops) and
kilometric (regional distribution and thickness of sedimentary facies compiled from wells).

Data from eleven outcrop sections with facies analysis and sampling were used to build a

depositional model for the ca¡bonate and evaporite facies. Data from 43 wells were also used

for mapping of the carbonate facies distribution and thickness using Geographic Information

System software. This allows the characterization ofthe spatial distribution, isopachs and the

frequency of occurrence of ca¡bonate facies. The sedimentary facies were defined on the basis

of their geometry, sedimentary structures, grain size, sorting, packing, alobiochemical grains,

matrix as well as textures associated with eodiagenetic processes. Paleocurrent analysis was

performed to provide information about the directions of sediment transpoft. Seventy two thin

sections were made for petrographical analysis under the optical microscope and scanning

electron microscope (SEM). This analysis aimed to characferize the morphology of fìne
grained depositional components, authigenic minerals and porosity. The thin sections were

stained with alizarine red and potassium ferricyanide diluted in 1.5% HCI to differentiate
carbonate minerals (Dickson, 1966). The thin sections were classified according to Dunham's

classification of carbonates (Dunham, 1969). The terminology for fossil microbialite of Grey

(1989) was used to classify and describe the stromatolite facies. Porosity was described

according to the proposal of Choquette and Pray (1970) and Pittman (1971). SEM analysis

were carried out on ca¡bon-coated polished thin sections.

5. Results

5.1 Sedimentary Facies

Carbonate facies are concentrated in the upper po(ion of the Teresina Formation.

Eight carbonate and evaporite facies were recognized within the eleven studied stratigraphic

sections. These facies occur intercalated with terrigenous sandy and muddy facies, which

occur as centimenter to meter tabular layers (from 20 cm to 4 m thickness), frequently

presenting ripple cross lamination, with concave-convex truncations and containing
centimeter length intraclasts of underlying lithologies. The heterolithic facies are interpreted

as result of alternation between traction and suspension sediment transport. The teruigenous

facies are mainly associated with bioclastic packstones and oolitic packstones-grainstones

(Fig. 4). The observed facies are described as follows.

28



Mudstone with ostracod shells

This facies comprises centimeter thick tabular layers (up to 10 cm thick). It is
composed of micrite with less than 7Vo of ostracod shells. These bioclasts are mainly
fragmented, with up to 1 mm length. Chert nodules (up to 10 cm diameter) and levels (up to 7

cm thickness) and, occasionally, mudstone-chert breccia facies are intercalated with this
facies. The carbonate is dominated by calcite. Calcite and dolomite with chevron texture in

cubic crystals (Fig.3C,D) are interpreted as halite pseudomorphs (1 to 5 pm diameter). Calcite

occurs as sword-shaped crystals, interpreted as replacing gypsum (Fig.3C,E). Dolomite occurs

as rhombohedral crystals with hypidiomorphic texture. The sizes of rhombohedral crystals

range between 20 and 200 pm and they can be sparse or concentrated as crystals mosaics

(Fig.3F). These crystals can form submillimeter levels close to chert nodules or levels or
occur intercalated with these levels (Fig.3F). Scanning electron microscopy analysis shows

micrometric cubic crystals of halite (Fig.7C). Autighenic quartz was identified as bipiramidal

crystals with length from 50 to 100 ¡rm. The hopper texture suggests an original salt
precipitate, which forms by evaporation of shallow waters and dissolution ofthe halite crystal.

This arrangement is characteristic of shallow water saline environments (Tucker, 2001). The

autighenic quartz is often found in carbonates affected by saline or hypersaline pore waters

(Flügel, 2004). The presence of evaporite minerals, autighenic quartz, chert nodules and
levels would indicate arid periods suitable for chemical precipitation. The intercalation of this

facies (Fig.4) with breccias indicates periodic subaerial exposure. This facies was deposited

by suspension of micritic mud in shallow waters from arid or semi-arid area close to
shoreline.

Peloidal mudstone

This facies comprises centimetric tabular layers (up to 10 cm thick). It is composed

mostly of peloids, with up to 2 mm diameter. This facies presents fenestrae cavities
(birdseyes), with lengths between 20 ¡.rm and 2 mm. The space between peloids is filled with

blocky calcite, gypsum or chalcedony (Fig. 5B), which can be connected verlically and

horizontally. This facies is associated with the chert nodules (diameters between 2 to 10 cm)

and breccias facies.

Lamination types include wrinkled, lenticular, discontinuous and irregularly variable.

Bioclasts are represented by ostracod disarticulated shells, that occur as isolated or forming

thin and continuous sub-miiimetric, well-sorted laminae (300 pm thick). Shell fragments are

mostly replaced by spary calcite. Quartz can occur as scattered grains or as concentrations

associated with dolomite laminae. In the calcite laminae, quartz grains does not exceed l0o%

by volume. Cheft nodules are sparse, with diameter up to 2 cm. The low diversity of bioclasts

shows ecologically stressful conditions, as high salinity or high concentration of specific ions.

The concentration of ostracod shells in submillimeter levels suggests trapping and fixing of

these particles by the microbial activity. This facies is interpreted as microbial mats developed

under low-moderate energy conditions. The flat lamination and morphology would indicate

areas partially protected with low intensity of wave action and proximity to the shoreline
(Hoffman, 1976). This facies is interpreted as product of deposition in a shallow water
environment, frequently flooded promoting the development of microbial mat. Disrupted

lamination is interpreted as the result of desiccation due to sporadic subaerial exposure. These

features occur at the top ofthe bed, indicating gradual shallowing deposition under conditions

of arid climate and hypersalinity.

Oolitic packstone and grainstone

Oolitic packstone and grainstone occur as cross-stratified tabular beds or amalgamated

lenses of thickness between 0.2 m (Santo Antonio da Platina site) and 3 m (Farlura site). This

facies is intercalated with sandstones, bioclastic packstones and heterolithic facies (Fig. 8).

Ooids are composed of calcite or dolomite, being poorly softed, fine to coarse grained (with

diameters between 50 pm and 1 mm), ovoid or spherical shape, with, 80% of them presenting

radial structure. Terrigenous grains represent up to 10% of the rock and are dominated by

quartz with minor amounts of feldspar. Ooids are formed by coating of terrigenous grains and

shell fragments. Bioclasts comprise approximately 8% of the rock, being represented by fish

remains and minor amounts of ostracod shells. Grains are closely packed. The proportion of

dolomitic ooids varies between 30%o and 45% in Santo Antônio da Platina and between 20

and 35%o in Farlura. In the oolitic grainstone and packstone facies, the primary porosity was

occluded by sparry calcite. Some ooids present intraparticle portions filled by microcrystalline

quaftz and chalcedony, suggesting total or partial dissolution before cementation.

grainstones are interpreted as deposited in medium-high energy settings in shallow waters,

with constant wave and/or current agitation. When this facies occurs as centimetric lenses,

they are frequently upon erosive bases, indicating reworking, possibly by storm-waves. The

high degree of fragmentation of the bioclasts also indicates reworking.

Nodular and enterolithic chert

The layers are up to 16 cm thick and nodules up to 10 cm length. This facies is

composed principally of microcrystalline and chalcedony quartz, with crystals of iruegular,

subrounded and rounded shapes. Frequently, this facies is associated with mudstones and

wackstones facies. Layers may present enterolithic structure (Fig. 6A,B,C) and structures

similar to tepees (Fig. 6F). Petrographic analysis revealed the presence of length-slow

chalcedony in the enterolithic layers. The chert nodules and layers are interpreted as replaced

evaporites. The enterolithic structure of these levels may represent deformation and collapse

of evaporite laminae.

The overlying lithology is deformed and fill space between fragments. The tepee
structures suggest desiccation process. The presence of length-slow chalcedony within
enterolithic layers is strongly suggestive of a high salinity depositional or early diagenetic

environment (Tucker, 2001; Folk and Pittman, 1971). This facies is produced by sediment

settling in shallow and low-energy waters, with periods of intense evaporation and
precipitation of evaporite minerals.

Mudstone-chert breccia

Breccias occur as milimetric to centimetric laminae ( I mm to 3 cm thick), mainly
associated with the wackestone and mudstone facies. The breccias consist of angular to

subrounded fragments of chert with a major lengths between submillimeter to I cm (Fig. 6H).

According to the nomenclature of Morrow (1982), these breccias may be classified as crackle

to mosaic breccias.

The clasts are closely fitted in the central pafi and loosely towards the ends, being

sometimes spatially independent. Contacts between clasts are ragged, microfragment

armouring, jagged, solution rounded and pitted. The breccias is matrix-supported. The space

between clasts is filled chiefly by micrite and secondary by calcite and dolomite spar cements

(Fig. 6H). Dolomite crystals are concentrated mainly in the upper portion ofthe breccia, with

10 to 200 pm length (Fig. 3A).

The analysis under scanning electron microscope reveals the presence of gypsum and

autighenic barite with strontium. Barite and gypsum occur as isolated and euhedral crystals, as

cement filling the space between calcite crystals and chert nodules, replacing calcite and

dolomite or as aggregated masses (Fig.7A,B). Petrographic analysis revealed fractures within

the nodules filled with anhydrite (Fig. 3B). Autighenic quaúz was identified as bypiramidal

crystals of 50 to 300 pm long and frequently associated with blocky calcite cement and

chalcedony (Fig. 5D).

In some sections, desiccation cracks were observed in the muddy sediments below

chert nodules. The overlying lithology is deformed and fills space between chert fragments.

The evaporite minerals such as gypsum and anhydrite may be dissolved, creating solution-

collapse breccias and increasing porosity. This facies was deposited by settling of fine

sediments in suspension in shallow and quiet waters, with periods of subaerial exposure

producing dissolution of evaporite minerals.

6. Discussion

6.1 Controls on carbonate and evaporite sedimentation in the Teresina Formation

The depositional systems of the Paranâ Basin are dominated by terrigenous sediments.

Carbonate and evaporite sediments are restricted in time and space, being present only during

the Permian, since the deposition of the Irati Formation (Hachiro, 1996). The carbonate and

evaporite facies of the Teresina Formation record a shift for a condition of low terrigenous

input in a shallow depositional environment during the end of Permian. Identified features in

the study region such as collapse breccias, evaporite minerals and their pseudomorphs,

silicified or calcitizied nodules interpreted as replacement of evaporites, presence of
quartzine, authigenic idiomorphic quartz crystals, as well as the low diversity but abundant

skeletal grains are suggestive of saline and hypersaline depositional conditions (Flüge|,2004).

Also, stromatolites with flat morphology, presence of Lycopodiopsis fragments with low
sedimentary transport (De Faria et al., 2009) and desiccation cracks are others evidences

suggestive of shallow and restrict depositional environment. The heterolithic silty-sandy
facies and fragmented stems and leafs of Lycopodiopsrs were probably deposited by storm

events, as De Faria et al. (2009) suggested for silicified stems of Lycopodiopsis derbyi from

42



the Teresina and Corumbataí formations in the reigion nothward the PGA. This vegetal fossil

is an indicator ofarid conditions (De Faria et a|.,2009).

The carbonate and evaporite facies of the Teresina Formation would record
sedimentary environments of low-energy ramp protected by oolitic sand bars, with frequent

hypersaline conditions and under the influence of waves and associated currents (Fig. 10).

The spatial and stratigraphical distribution of the carbonate and evaporite facies indicates a

restricted area with lower terrigenous input that was isolated progressively from open waters.

In periods of high runoff, the water level raised and the storms and strong winds provoked

increase of the terrigenous input and remobilization of bottom sediments. The entries of sea

water were restricted and were controlled by the PGA. The protected areas behind the oolitic

bars promoted the deposition of frne sediments, allowing the formation of muddy flats where

the mudstone with ostracod shells, peloidal mudstones and tabular boundstones facies were

deposited. During periods of intense evaporation, nodular and enterolithic sulphates and
mudstone-sulphate breccia facies were deposited in an onshore sabkha exposed to dissolution

processes. These evaporites sulphates were replaced by cherl during diagenesis. The bioclastic

wackstones and oolitic packstone-grainstone were deposited in offshore zones directly
influenced by waves. During the storm events, coarser sediments were transported to distal

parts. The sedimentation of these facies was between the fairweather and the storm wave

base. The deposition of proximal and distal sediments alternates during fair and storm weather

periods, respectively. During storm episodes, the sabkha is flooded and the lime mud is

transported and deposited on it, forming a mud surface. When the water level decreased, the

intense evaporation produced dessication cracks and evaporite minerals precipitation.

Others authors have been observed evidences of enclosed environment in the Teresina

Formation in the studied area. Ghilardi and Simões (2002) consider that the endemism of

bivalves of the Serra Alta, Teresina and Corumbataí formations is promoted by the gradual

geographic isolation of the Paraná Basin. Rohn (1994) indicates that after the deposition of

the Irati Formation, the basin becoming similar to a large closed lake (sea-lake), with low

amounts of rainfall influencing changes in water level and salinity. The Corumbataí
Formation, which is the Teresina Formation equivalent unit, is located to the nofth of the

Tietê Lineament. Its sedimentation is predominantly terrigenous, without significant
carbonate facies deposition. This could mean larger amounts of pluviosity and run off in the

northern portion of the Paraná Basin during the Late Permian, with the carbonate and

evaporite sedimentation concentrated in the region to the south of the Tietê Lineament and to

the north ofthe PGA axis.

6.2 Implications for the paleogeography of the southwestern Gondwana during the
Permian

Summons et al. (2008) suggest that the Paraná Basin, the Falkland Islands, the

Kalahari Basin (southern Namibia), and the Karoo Basin (South Africa) probably formed a

huge cratonic basin in the southwest porlion of the Gondwana. This basin was apparently

isolated from the world oceans as it has been corroborated by the observed endemic fauna.

During the Permo-Triassic times, the southern margin of the Gondwana was affected by the

Gondwanide Orogeny, producing deformation, metamorphism and magmatic-arc activity

(Trouw and De Wit, 1999). During this time, the colisional event that originates the San

Rafael Orogeny probably influenced the structural framework of the Paraná Basin, producing

changes in its depositional settings and source areas through the generation of local
depressions and highs. In this context, Milani (2000) observed the inversion of the on-lap

trend in the supersequence Gondwana I, which comprise the Teresina Formation.

According to Stollhofen (1999), a rift valley depression linked to the opening of the

South Atlantic between Africa and South America was affected by extensional events since

the Late Carboniferous. During the deposition ofthe Irati Formation, this depression extended

from the west of South Africa to the northern Brazil. According to this author, later the

Corumbataí Formation was deposited in the rift west margin. The rift was controlled by a

long-lived nofth-nofthwest trending tectonic zonation, inducing the formation of transfer fault

zones transversal to the rift valley axis and promoting the formation of various depocenters

that were linked during water highstands. The PGA may be one of these fault zones
perpendicular to the main rift trend (Stollhofen el al., 2000). Thus, the carbonate and
evaporite facies of the Teresina Formation would be deposited in a tectonic-controlled

45



facies deposited in alluvial systems from the Pirambóia Formation in the northern flank of the

PGA agrees with its tectonic activity during the Permo-Triassic (Giannini et a|.,2004).

The Huab Basin in west Africa is interpreted as a Gondwana marginal equivalent of

the Paraná Basin (Horsthemke et al., 1990) (Fig. I l). The Gai-As Formation of the Huab

Basin has an age of 265+2.5 Ma (Holzforster, 2002) while to the Teresina Formation was

assigned an age of 267*1.7 Ma (Rocha-Campos et a1.,2009). The Teresina Formation would

be equivalent to Gai-As Formation, which was deposited in a rift lake system. Horsthemke

(1992) interpreted the limestones layers with evaporitic minerals (halite and gypsum) founded

in the Gai-As and the Doros Formation, which overlies to The Gais-As Formation, as formed

in alkaline-saline lake environment. The sedimentation of the Teresina Formation would have

been influenced by tectonic and climate controls, which also acted on the correlate units of the

Huab Basin. The similarity between the lithologies and environmental conditions of the Gai-

As and Teresina formations suggest a commom subsidence zone under arid conditions.

7, Conclusions

During the Permian, the deposition of the ca¡bonate and evaporite facies of the
Teresina Formation would result fiom the combined influence of a wind convergence zone

and the geographic isolation linked to the tectonic evolution of the southwest Gondwana. The

Ponta Grossa Arch influenced the climate conditions of the Permian-Triassic formations of

the Paraná Basin, acting as a geographical barrier controlling the winds, run-off, entry of sea

waters from south and biological exchange. These features dictate the development of a high

salinity water body and arid conditions in the studied region. A probable wind convergence
zone located paralallel to the Ponta Grossa Arch influenced the periodic sedimentation of
carbonate and evaporite facies of the Teresina Formation. The migration of this wind
convergence zone to the south would promote arid conditions in the studied zone. The
comparison between the Teresina F'ormation and the Gai-As and Doros formations from the

Huab Basin provides valuable information about the possible evolution ofa Permian rift zone

in the Brazilian and African parts of the southwestern Gondwana.

ABSTRACT

Stromatolites layers of the Teresina Formation (Late Permian) was identified in the

eastern border of the Paraná Basin at north of the Paraná State (Brazil). These stromatolites

stand out due to its calcite-dolomite lamination and well preserved organic structures. The

genesis of these stromatolites and their calcite-dolomite lamination are discussed in the

context of the Permian-Triassic Boundary Miclobialites (PTBMs). The dolomite bands are

enriched in organic matter as identified by fluorescence microscopy. The precipitation of

dolomite would be linked to mineral precipitation induced by biological processes. The

organic structures identified were filamentous and nanoglobules, forming biofilms. All these

organic structures are known as extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) and are the

principal source of energy for metabolic processe of sulphate-reducing bacteria. Polyhedra of

EPS showing initial stages of growth of the stromatolites were observed. The biof,rlms would

corespond to thin laminae of calcite-dolomite precipitated. The high degree of preservation

of the remains of degraded EPS is related to early calcification processes. Hypersaline

conditions promoted stressful environmental conditions and microbial activy, inhibiting

favorable conditions for development of other organisms and fauna diversification. The low

content of terrigenous grains indicates that the dominant mechanism for stromatolite
formation is biologically induced mineral precipitation.

Keywords: stromatolites, Late Permian, Teresina Formation, bacterial biofilms, dolomite.

I. INTRODUCTION
Stromatolites are considered the most ancient biological feature and the major constituent

of fossil record, being the earliest evidence of the emergence of life on Eafih (Seckbach,

2010). They are the result of the trapping, binding and precipitation of sediment by the

extracellular polymeric matrix (EPS) produced by the organisms-biofilms (Krumbein, 1994).

Biofilms are defined as a collection of microorganisms and their extracellular products bound

to a solid surface (N,leu, 1994).

Stromatolites are widely used as paleoenvironmental indicators. Its development is

controlled by physical and chemical factors, such as temperature, salinity, water depth, wave

and tidal energy and dissolved oxygen concentration. Stromatolites are common sedimentary

features in proterozoic carbonate rocks, which is attributed to the absence of competing

carbonate-skeletal organisms (Knoll, 1993). During the Phanerozoic, the generation of

stromatolites is favored in environments with hypersaline waters, whose conditions diffrcult

the growing of carbonate-skeletal organisms. Well preserved structures of the stromatolites

microbial components are rare.

The Teresina Formation (White, 1908; Milani ¿¡ a1.,2007; Holz et a1.,2010), Late

Permian of the Paraná Basin, is highghted by the presence of calcite-dolomite stromatolite

layers with impressive well preserved microscopic organic structures. The Teresina Formation

stromatolites developed in the context of the Permian-Triassic Boundary Microbialites

(PTBMs), which are thin (0.05-15 m thick) microbialites associated with shelly faunas and

whose growing was favored by global environmental changes responsible for the end-Permian

mass extinction (Kershaw eT a1.,2012). The PTBMs are mainly reported in low latitudes of

the Tethys sea. The objective of this paper is to describe the structures preserved in

stromatolites layers ofthe Teresina Formation and discuss their ecological significance for the

Gondwana epicontinental seas during the Late Permian.

2, THE TERESINA FORMATION
The Teresina Formation (Passa Dois Group) outcrops along the eastern edge of the

Paraná Basin (Milani et al., 2007). This unit is composed of tabular decimeter to meter thick

layers of heterolithic laminated siltstones and fine-grained sandstones, limestones (oolitic and

bioclastic grainstones and packstones, wackestones and stromatolites). The proportion and

thickness of carbonate facies are greater norlhward the Ponta Grossa Arch axis, where it was

developed a carbonate-evaporite ramp depositional system recorded in the upper porlion of

55



the Teresina Formation (Mendez and Sawakuchi, submitted). The studied outcrop occurs in

the northern flank of the Ponta Grossa Arch, at the north of the Paraná State, in the

municipality of Santo Antônio da Platina (Fig. 1).

Rohn (2001) suggests an age near the Cisuralian - Guadalupian limit (Middle Permian)
for the Teresina Formation. Some plant fossils identified are Lycopodiopsls, which have been

assignated an age of Cisuralian and Guadalupian for the Teresina and Corumbataí formations

(De Faria et al., 2009). Holz et al. (2010) indicated an older age of Late Kungurian - Rodian
(Early to Middle Permian). However, the endemic fossil assemblage of the Teresina
Formation difficults its precise chronostratigraphical position. Rocha-Carnpos el al. (2009)

obtained an U/Pb age of 267+1.7 Ma (Late Permian) from zircon grains from ash-fall beds of

the Teresina Formation. The fossil content is represented mainly by bivalves, which are

endemic to the Paraná Basin (Simoes et a1.,1998), and occur commonly in carbonate facies.

The influence of marine conditions is not well defined yet. Almeida and Do Ca¡mo

(2005) considered some ostracods as marine. But Sohn and Rocha-Campos (1990) suggested

freshwater environment. Others bioclasts are fish remains (scales, teeth and dental plates) and

rare amphibian teeth, occurring in bone beds or scattered (Holz et al.,2010). Other authors

have recognized the presence of Permian stromatolites in the Teresina and Corumbataí

formations. Rohn (2001), Rohn sl al. (2003) and Meglhioratti (2006) registered stromatolitic

levels in the Teresina Formation. Rohn and Fairchild (1986) observed microbian communities

colonizing bivalve shells. Fairchild et al. (1991) identified columnar stromatolites and

Maranhão (1995) described silicifed domal and stratiform stromatolites. Stromatolites in the

Corumbataí Formation were described by Soares (1972) and Suguio et a/. (1985).

3. MATERIALSANDMETHODS
The sedimentary facies associated with the studied stromatolites were described, with the

facies assemblage being presented through a columnar section. Samples of the stromatolite

layers were collected for petrographical studies. The thin sections were stained with alizarine

red and potassium ferricyanide diluted in 1.5% HCI to differentiate calcite and dolomite

minerals under a light polarized microscope. Thin sections were also analysed with

fluorescence microscopy to identify content and distribution of organic malter (Perrette et al.,

2005). Scanning electron microscopy (sEM) analysis was made on freshly broken surfaces,

with the samples being gold-coated to study the stromatolite textures. The classification of

stromatolite morphology is based on the nomenclature proposed by Grey (1989).

4. RESULTS
4.1 Stromatolite beds and associated facies

The studied stromatolite layer has an uniform thickness of 47 cm (Fig 2). It is a fabular

lithostrome with laminations spacing very closed. The lamination types are wrinkled,

lenticular, discontinuos and irregularly variable (Grey, 1989). The discontinuous and inegular

lamination can be caused by desiccation promoted by sporadic subaerial exposure. Its

morphology is ondulatory and non-columnar. The stromatolite facies is associated with

heterolithic sandstones facies, which occur as tabular layer, with centimeter to meter thickness

(up to 4 m), presenting concave-convex truncament and ripple-marks (Fig. 3). The heterolithic

facies is interpreted ad deposited under the action of storm waves and associated currents in a

ramp between the fair-weather wave base and storm wave base. During these storm episodes,

large amounts of sediments are remobilized and deposited from suspension (silt and clay) and

traction (sand) loads. Bioclastic packstones occur intercalated in the heterolithic laminated

sandstones.

4.2 Stromatolite lamination

Petrographic analysis reveals that stromatolite lamination occurs as submillimetric to

milimetric alternations of calcite and dolomite bands (Fig. 4A,B,D,F). Teruigenous
components (up to 15%) are mainly quartz, feldspar and muscovite, occurring as scattered

grains or concentrated in the dolomite levels. The siliciclastic grains (up to 40 pm diarneter)

are concentrated in dolomite levels. Chert nodules with diameters between 3 cm and 200 pm

are sparse and deform the lamination, suggesting their genesis before significant mechanical

compaction. The groundmass is micrite. Toward the top level, blocky spar calcite and

chalcedony occur as cements filling microfractures and channels, with 10 to 400 ¡.rm length

and 10 to 100 pm thick, interrupting and deforming the laminafion. The proportion of calcite

to dolomite varies from 30:70 to 40:60.

Discussion

The shape and lamination type of the stromatolites are directly linked to the water

energy of the depositional environment (Logan et al., 1974). Many authors also recognized

that the morphology of the stromatolites is related to the water energy and therefore to their

proximity to the coastline (Donaldson and Taylor, I 972; Donaldson , 1976l" Grotzinger, 1989).

Stromatolite morphology changes from flat to columnar and domal shapes in the offshore

direction (Yamamoto et al.,20Il). Thus, the flat morphology of the analyzed stromatolite

would correspond to an environment of shallow waters with low action ofwaves and currents.

The environments of formation of the stromatolites are characterized by high chemical

gradients, abundance of phototrophic microorganisms and the separation of microbial
populations in different layers (Riding and Awramik, 2000). In fhe studied region, it was

identified centimeter nodules and enterolithic layers of chert, that are interpreted as evaporite

deposits replaced by silica during the diagenesis. These deposits indicate that the Teresina

Formation stromatolites evolved in an environment ofhigh salinities and intense evaporation.

The well preserved lamination occurs at the base of the studied stromatolite level.

Towards the top, the lamination is destroyed progressively by microchannels and fractures.

This indicates that the water level decreased gradually, producing desiccation cracks by air

exposure. The geochemical data of the carbonate rocks from the Teresina Formation are

indicative of high salinities, showing evaporitic conditions during its deposition (Suguio e/

aI.,1974, Stollhofen et a\.,2000). Thus, hypersaline shallow waters favored the development

of microbial mats in the Teresina Formation. This would be similar to microbial mats

developed due to hypersaline conditions during the Miocene in the Meditenanean region,

which records periods of intense evaporation as result of the isolation of the Mediterranean

Sea from the world ocean (Oliveri et a1.,2010).

In the petrographic analysis, the only fossils observed in the studied stromatolite bed

were ostracods shells. This low faunistic diversity could mean that environmental conditions

were stressful during microbial mat development and only ostracods could adapt to this

stressful environment. The abrupt contact between the stromatolite level and underlying

64



heterolithic facies deposited in relatively deeper water suggests a sudden drop of water level.
'fhe presence of most ostracods species is limited by seasonal variations in water temperature

(Forester, 1985) and hydrochemistry (Forester and Brouwers, 1985). As well as stromatolites,

ostracods can be valuable diagnostic indicators of water composition in ancient lakes. For

example, some species only occur in SO¿ rich waters, and others in water with high
concentration of Cl- (Forester, 1986). The presence of ostracods associated with evaporation

can indicate high contents of SO¿ in the water, favoring the development of microbial
communities of sulphate reduction bacteria.

The dolomite origin in stromatolite still is a debate subject still especially regarding if
its origin is primary by direct precipitation from sea water or secondary by diagenesis. In the

last decades, some works have demonstrated that the precipitation of dolomite is induced by

microbial activity (Vasconcelos e/ al., L995). Oliveri e/ al. (2010) proposed that the
precipitation of dolomite would be linked to bacterial sulphate reduction, which can remove

the sulphate and release Mg2t. As well as pyrite and NH¡ are produced bacterially, increasing

the pH and promoting alkalinization of the environment would induce the dolomite
precipitation. Organic matter such EPS is used in this process by the bacteria as energy

source.

Robafts and Zohary (1987) proposed that the warm vvater promotes the cyanobacterial

growth. In periods of greater evaporation due to warmer climate, the concentration of sulfates

increases and therefore, the food source for this type of bacteria increases, favoring the
precipitation of dolomite. Thus, the dolomite levels of the studied stromatolite would
represent periods of warmer and arid climate with intense evaporation and microbiâl activity.

This would explain the higher concentration of organic matter in the dolomite levels relative

to the calcite levels. van Lith et al. (2002) suggest that sulphate reduction and elevated salinity

are the main causes of dolomite precipitation in Lagoa Vermelha and Brejo do Espinho

lagoons (Brazil). The well preserved biofilms in the stromatolites of the Teresina Formation

would be caused by the calcihcation of the EPS. According to the microbial calcification

model, this process is metabolically induced and is essential to the preservation, distribution

and abundance of stromatolites in time and space (Riding, 2000). However, the organic

nanostructures observed in the Teresina Formation could correspond to biofilms developed in

rock microfractures and cavities. The high degree ofpreservation of the biofilms may suggest

organic structures younger than the Late Permian. The Early Cretaceous hydrothermal event

(Nomura et al., s\bmitted), could promote growth of microbial communities within fractures

of the Teresina Formation.

65



The low content of terrigenous grains indicates a low clastic supply during the
formation of stromatolites in the Teresina Formation. The concentration of the terrigenous

grains and ostracod shells in dolomite levels, probably, was produced by microbial activity

through trapping and binding processes by EPS.

Burns ¿l al. (2000) suggest a relation between the global environmental changes and

dolomite formation during the Phanerozoic, taking into account the declining abundance of

dolomite. According the information available, the age of the Teresina Formation may range

from Early Permian to Triassic. The Permian-Triassic stands out due to the occurrence of a

global mass extinction event, whose causes ¿ue still debated (senszl Fügel,2004). According

to Schubert and Bottj er (1992), the occurrences of stromatolites increased during the Late

Permian and Trisassic (Fig. 8). Kearsey et al. (2009) based on stable isotope analysis inferred

increasing of the sea surface temperature in the Late Permian. Disaster forms are
opportunistic taxa, typically of long stratigraphic range, which normally occur in marginal

and environmentally unstable settings but become abundant and environmentally widespread

during times of biotic crisis (sensa Fischer and Arthtr, 1977). The stromatolites of the
Teresina Formation probably could be related to the Permo-Triassic extinction, which is

characlerized by the expansion of the microbialites in nearshore ramp, platform interior and

slope settings (Mata and Bottjer,2012).

Conclusions

Stromatolites of the Teresina Formation in the study region would indicate stressful

environmental conditions such as elevated salinity and evaporation caused by rising
temperatures and/or less runoff. The stromatolite morphology is suggestive of proximity to

the shoreline in low energy setting with restricted tenigenous input. The high degree of
preservation of the organic nanostructures is related to early calcification of EPS. The
dolomite precipitation would occur during warmer periods with intense microbial activity.

The dolomite precipitation was result of biologically induced mineral precipitacion. The

stromatolites of the Teresina Formation could be linked to disaster forms associated with

mass extinction events. Thus, the Teresina Formation would record PTBMs in the
southwestern Gondwana.
